Machine learning models are often represented as scalar functions 
$$f:\mathcal{S}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$$ 
from a collection of _possible worlds_ (or a _sample space_) \\(\mathcal{S}\\) to reals \\(\mathbb{R}\\) that 
measure our confidence or belief that a possible world is the true world. Here a possible world could be (word,part-of-speech-tag) pair, or something more structured 
such as a sequence of observations and labels. 

In Wolfe you develop such scalar functions, and the
first step is to define the collection of possible worlds \\(\mathcal{S}\\). Wolfe uses
scala [iterables](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/2.10.4/index.html#scala.collection.Iterable) 
as collections of possible worlds (we could restricted us 
to scala sets but they are cases where order and duplicate items are useful). 

While you can in theory use any expression that yields a scala iterable 
as your collection of possible worlds, Wolfe is optimized for a limited set we 
describe below.
Atomic Worlds

Say we want to classify words as nouns or verbs. At the core of this task is an _atomic_ collection
of labels, in this case "Noun" and "Verb." In Wolfe you can use simple scala iterables to define
such atomic collections, such as a [List](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/2.10.3/index.html#scala.collection.immutable.List).
List("Verb","Noun")

Of course scala [Range](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/2.10.3/index.html#scala.collection.immutable.Range)
objects can serve as collections of possible worlds as well.
0 until 5
Multivariate Worlds

In practice possible worlds have several interacting components. For example, 
in the case of part-of-speech classification a token has a word and a part-of-speech,
and the former helps to determine the latter. In Wolfe such worlds can be 
described using Scala [case classes](http://www.codecommit.com/blog/scala/case-classes-are-cool). 

To compactly describe a (factorized) collection of case class worlds, Wolfe provides the `all` method.
This method takes as first argument a case class name (or rather, the case class constructor)
and as second argument an iterable of tuples ordered according to the order of 
case class fields. In the example below we use the `x` operator to create such a
collection of tuples as cartesian product of possible words and possible labels.
`all` then creates all possible `Token` objects corresponding to these tuples.

case class Token(word:String, label:String)
val words = List("eat","house")
val labels = List("Verb","Noun")
all(Token) { words x labels }

When case classes have many fields, and evolve over time, maintaining the correct order of the 
cartesian product can become tedious. Assuming each field has 
a different scala type, we can avoid this problem by declaring the arguments of the
cartesian product using scala implicits. Below you see the above example adapted
to use the [Symbol](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/2.10.3/index.html#scala.Symbol) 
class as label in order to make field types unique.

implicit val impWords = List("eat","house")
implicit val impLabels = List('Verb,'Noun)
all(Token)
Sequences

Many real world problems, such as tagging in NLP, or gene sequencing,
concern sequences of objects. In Wolfe `seqs(worlds,maxLength)` takes a collection
of possible worlds `worlds` and generates all possible sequences over these worlds
up to a maximum length `maxLength`.

val tags = List("Verb","Noun")
seqs(tags, 2)

The base collection of possible worlds can be any scala iterable. In particular, it can be
possible worlds constructed using other operators.
seqs(all(Token){List("eat") x List("Verb")}, 2)
Maps

Wolfe supports the Scala [Map](http://www.scala-lang.org/api/2.10.4/index.html#scala.collection.immutable.Map) class to 
represent mappings from a domain to a range. Such mappings can be very useful, for example 
to represent relations and graphs, as shown in the example below. To generate 
all possible maps from a domain `dom` to a range `range` use the `maps(dom,range)`
function.

val nodes = 0 until 2
val bools = List(false,true)
maps(nodes x nodes,bools).take(2)
Predicates

In Wolfe predicates are special cases of maps from some domain to {true,false}. 
As they are frequently useful, Wolfe provide syntactic sugar to make their use easier.

case class Person(name:String)
case class World(smokes:Pred[Person])
val persons = List(Person("Anna"),Person("Bob"))
preds(persons).take(2)
Infinite Collections

Often we need infinite collections of possible worlds. For example,
a possible world may have real-valued attributes, and hence there are infinitely
many possibilities unless with discretize the attribute. Another example
are string attributes such as the word of a token. Given that people constantly produce 
new words, and typos, such string attributes can be considered infinite as well.

In Wolfe infinite collections can be constructed with the `infty[T]` 
method that returns an infinite collection of type `T`. Note that such
collections really only serve as placeholders, and one cannot iterate
over the infinite collection. Because of this, Wolfe currently 
__requires infinite attributes to be observed__.
//todo: all(Token){infty[String] x List('Verb,'Noun)}
Built-in Collections

Wolfe comes with a set of built in collections of possible worlds that can be used to 
construct more complex ones.

//val bools = List(false,true)
val doubles = infty[Double]
val strings = infty[String]
val vectors = infty[Vector]
